newsitem.title: USA: Arkansas gambling amendment backers want judge removed.
newsitem.headline: Arkansas gambling amendment backers want judge removed.

text.p: Backers of a gambling amendment booted off Arkansas' Nov 5 ballot have filed for a rehearing, and want a special justice disqualified from the case.

The Arkansas Supreme Court Monday announced a four to three vote to remove Amendment 7 because of ballot title problems, according to release issued by The Committee to Promote Arkansas, which supports Amendment 7. The constitutional amendment called for a state-wide lottery, charity bingo and limited casino gaming.

Amendment supporters want Special Justice Sandra Smith Hochstetter disqualified from the case "because of a perceived conflict of interest," the release said. Hochstetter, who cast the deciding vote, was appointed by Gov. Mike Huckabee after another justice, Robert Brown, recused himself due to a conflict of interest, it said.

According to the release, Hochstetter is assistant general counsel for a business called Arkla Gas. Arkla is represented by Friday Eldredge & Clark, a law firm that also represents Amendment 4, a gaming amendment in competition with Amendment 7. A Friday Eldredge attorney who argued the Amendment 4 case before the court, also represents Arkla, the release said.

"The appearance of impropriety is what we're talking about here," David Couch, an Amendment 7 attorney, said. "If one of my clients was sitting in judgment of the case involving Oaklawn, I don't think they'd be very happy about that."
Oaklawn Park is one of the proposed casino sites.
Couch cited copies of a circuit court case filed in May 1996 in which Arkla is represented by Friday Eldredge. Justice Hochstetter could not be reached immediately for comment.
The release added that in 1994, backers of Amendment 7 put forth a similar measure that was stricken two weeks before the election.
"In redrafting the amendment this time around, we followed the court's instructions from 1994," Couch said. "We followed their rules, but it seems the rules have been changed on us."
Amendment 7 was one of three gambling amendments removed from Arkansas ballot, making Amendment 4 the only gambling amendment left on the ballot.
